question: What organization provides drinking water to Denver residents?
incorrectFeedback: Denver Water provides drinking water to 1.5 million people in the Denver metro area, including all of the City & County of Denver. If you'd like to learn more, check out this video!

question: What major river runs through downtown Denver?
correctFeedback: Correct! There are other tributaries that cut through the City as well, such as Cherry Creek. The South Platte runs all the way to Nebraska, and from there to Missouri, Mississippi, and the Gulf of Mexico
incorrectFeedback: The South Platte River starts in the Rocky Mountains and travels down through Denver on its way to Nebraska. Visit Confluence Park to see where it meets Cherry Creek and where Denver began!
Reviewer Comments (Not visible to public: Some might argue that Cherry Creek also runs through downtown, though I don't know if that's technically true. Any thought about adding Cherry Creek into the mix? It's an equally important player in One Water in the greater Denver area, but it's also been historically the Platte's equal -- especially when you consider that the city started where it did because of the confluence of the two water ways. Bond, Denver Water.

question: What happens to water flushed down a toilet in Denver?
choice1: It is piped straight to the ocean
choice2: It is injected into the ground
choice3: It goes to a water reclamation facility that cleans it and returns it to the environment
correctFeedback: Correct! In Denver, most toilets flow to Metro Water Recovery's water reclamation facility on the South Platte just north of downtown, where it is treated and safely returned to the environment.
incorrectFeedback: In Denver, most toilets flow to Metro Water Recovery's water reclamation facility on the South Platte just north of downtown, where it is treated and safely returned to the environment.
Reviewer Comments (Not visible to public: What if we added "...safely to the environment?" Bond, Denver Water.

question: Rain and snow are both examples of what part of the water cycle?
correctFeedback: That's right, precipitation, a major part of how water is tranported around the world!
incorrectFeedback: Precipitation is major component of how water moves around the earth in the water cycle. See if you can find it in this image!

question: What is the official name of Denver's government?
correctFeedback: That's right! The City and County of Denver is one of only two such consolidated city/county governments in Colorado.
incorrectFeedback: The City and County of Denver is the formal name for Denver's conslidated city/county government, one of only two such consolidated city/county governments in Colorado.

question: What year was the Denver One Water Plan published?
Reviewer Comments (Not visible to public: One might argue that this is a difficult question. I doubt many people outside us water geeks know this. Even I had to think about it and narrow down an answer. Bond, Denver Water.

choice1: The Gulf of California via the Colorado River

question: How big of a rain barrel can be used at an individual's home in Colorado?
Reviewer Comments (Not visible to public: I believe it's technically two barrels with a combined total capacity that doesn't exceed 110 gallons. Maybe the better wording is "How many gallons of rainwater can homeowners in Colorado legally capture?" I don't love that wording either. Bond, Denver Water.

question: How long has The Greenway Foundation been dedicated to Denver's waterways?
Reviewer Comments (Not visible to public: This is basically a repeat of question in row 12. I'd toss it because it will immediately become obsolete at the turn of the calendar year. Bond, Denver Water.

question: How much water does one toilet flush use?
Reviewer Comments (Not visible to public: This is a question that could be answered correctly a zillion ways. There are toilets that flush many different amounts. What's the ultimate point of the question? Is it about what the legal limit for toilet flush amounts in Colorado? If so, it's 1.28. I know they make ultra-high-efficiency toilets that use even less. Add urinals into the mix, which are "toilets" to many people, and things get even more confusing. It depends on what the ultimate goal of the learning that results from the question. Work backwards from there. Bond, Denver Water.

question: What creek flows into the South Platte River in Confluence Park?
correctFeedback: Yep! Cherry Creek begins south of Denver in El Paso Countyand flows into Cherry Creek Reservoir at Cherry Creek State Park, before joining the South Platte right downtown. Check out the trail from the reservoir to downtown sometime!
incorrectFeedback: Cherry Creek begins south of Denver in El Paso Countyand flows into Cherry Creek Reservoir at Cherry Creek State Park, before joining the South Platte right downtown. Check out the trail from the reservoir to downtown sometime!

Which of these home water uses typically conumes the most water?
correctFeedback: That's right! Toilets are typically the largest home water use, which is why many areas seek to replace old high-flow toilets with new low-flow ones!
incorrectFeedback: Actually, toilets are typically the largest home water use, which is why many areas seek to replace old high-flow toilets with new low-flow ones!

question: What is "One Water" ?
choice4: All of the Above (it's all One Water!)
correctFeedback: That's right! One Water is the concept that all water should be managed jointly, because while water goes through many stages and uses it's all a resource as One Water!
incorrectFeedback: One Water is the concept that all water should be managed jointly, because while water goes through many stages and uses it's all a resource as One Water!

question: What new (2021) agency in Denver's government works exclusively on climate mitigation and adaptation?
correctFeedback:
Denver's Office of Climate Action, Sustainability, & Resiliency or CASR is Denver's response to the climate crisis, with a dedicated funding source and a mission to mitigate climate causes, adapt to impacts, and build resiliency in Denver's communities. Want to learn more about CASR?

question: What department in the City and County of Denver is responsible for the system that carries stormwater runoff to the river?
correctFeedback:
Denver's Derpartment of Transportation and Instrastructure (DOTI) manages stormwater systems inside the City limits, and is responsible for ensuring that the stormwater that eventually reaches the South Platte is treated to remove pollutant loads and keep our waterways clean! Want to learn more about DOTI's stormwater quality work?

Click Here!
